title-group.article-title: Obtaining maximum exsanguination of the hand, preserving sterility, and avoiding trauma to the digits: a simple technique

body.p: Exsanguination of the hand and application of a tourniquet is a prerequisite for most hand surgery. Several techniques have been described, including the use of the Rhys-Davies exsanguinator (Rhys-Davies and Stotter, 1985), crepe bandage (Alshawi and Scott, 2004), simple limb elevation, gauze bandage, Esmarch bandage, Pomidor roll-cuff, Urias bag, and squeeze method (Blond and Madsen, 2002). The unsterile Rhys-Davies exsanguinator has been reported to be associated with an increased risk of transmission of infection (Ballal et al., 2007) and to be less effective than an Esmarch or crepe bandage (Alshawi and Scott, 2004). It is also, of necessity, applied before skin preparation and draping, thus increasing the ischaemia time. Comparison of different techniques has demonstrated that exsanguination is best achieved using the Esmarch bandage (Blond and Madsen, 2002). Usually this is wrapped around the bunched-up digits (Figure 1A). This may not exsanguinate all parts of the digits or palm (Figure 1B), and its application may be traumatic to digits compromised by arthritis or joint instability, because the digits are subjected to lateral trauma, not simple flexion. Furthermore, in the conscious patient, applying an Esmarch bandage to the bunched-up digits may be uncomfortable or painful.

caption.p: (A) The usual way of applying an Esmarch bandage to the hand. (B) Incomplete exsanguination of digits after tourniquet inflation.

body.p: We present a method of exsanguination that combines different techniques, utilizing their benefits and reducing their negative aspects. We routinely place a roll of sterile crepe bandage in the palm after skin preparation and draping, and invite the patient to grip the bandage tightly (Figure 2A). If the patient is anaesthetized, the bandage is simply placed in the palm. A sterile Esmarch bandage is then wrapped around the clenched fist and forearm, exsanguinating the limb (Figure 2B). The tourniquet is inflated. Placing a rolled crepe bandage in the palm, before applying the Esmarch bandage, supports the digits, protecting them from trauma. The even pressure achieved also thoroughly exsanguinates the digits and palm (Figure 3), without residual puddling. The use of this method after skin preparation and draping reduces ischaemia time.

caption.p: (A) Crepe bandage roll placed in the palm. (B) Esmarch bandaging of clenched fist and forearm.
Thorough exsanguination of digits after tourniquet inflation.
